[Mr Speaker in the Chair]



    Head L -

    The Chairman: Head L, Ministry of the Environment. Amendment No. (1), Dr Teo Ho Pin.

Column: 1452



    Dr Teo Ho Pin (Holland-Bukit Panjang): Sir, I beg to move,

    That the total sum to be allocated for Head L of the Main Estimates be reduced by $100.

    Sir, Singaporeans enjoy clean air, clean water and a clean living environment. This is mainly attributed to the Government's efforts in environment management. Over the last 30 years, three key strategies have been implemented to ensure that we have a clean and green environment, viz, planning, monitoring and enforcement.

    However, the new approach towards a sustainable environment is to involve all stakeholders in environment management efforts. We need to adopt new strategies to champion our sustainable development efforts for future generations of Singaporeans. We must also set new performance indicators for our environmental performance.

    Sir, I wish to ask the Minister the following questions:

    1) Can the Minister update the House on the environmental performance in Singapore?

    2) What are the measures taken to ensure clean air quality in Singapore?

    3) What are the achievements in waste management and recycling?

    4) What are the new measures taken to ensure better public health?

    The Chairman: We have 160 minutes for this amendment. Prof. Low.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay (Chua Chu Kang): Sir, I am going to talk about the pollution from 2-stroke engine motorcycles.

    The registration of 2-stroke engine motorcycles was stopped many years ago. After so many years of stoppage of new registration, there are still many such motorcycles running on our roads. The poor emission control of such vehicles is polluting the environment badly. The amount of unburned hydrocarbons, the

Column: 1453

bluish smoke from the burning of lubricants, and the odour have caused excessive pollution of our air, and are actually making it unbearable to our road users. It affects the health of both pedestrians and other road users. The pollution generated is so bad that one should avoid trailing any such vehicle or to open up the window immediately after you pass such vehicles.

    For road users like us, who have invested so heavily in anti-pollution equipment in our cars and new trucks - I guess we pay about $3,000-$6,000 per car, inclusive of tax - is it not only fair for all the road users that we consider phasing out such air-polluting machines from the road? The question I would like to ask is: would the Ministry agree that the 2-stroke motorcycle is a poorly fitted and air-polluting machine? Should not such 2-stroke motocycles be completely phased out from our roads? If not, what measures does the Ministry plan to take to improve the emission from such vehicles?

    Mr Othman Haron Eusofe (Marine Parade): Sir, I know that pneumonia is now a concern. The Minister for Health has given us the necessary answers and assurances, but we must take care and take necessary precautions. Now, I want to raise with the Minister for the Environment the issue of dengue. I know that there is no vaccine available now to treat dengue. So, the only way to prevent dengue is to have an effective vector control programme and to engage active public and community involvement in the programme.

    Sir, I would like to know whether the incidence of dengue is now under control, and what are the other preventive measures that the Ministry of the Environment is implementing to control the incidence of dengue.

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Aljunied): Sir, while we are sitting here today, 150 government ministers and Heads of States are now attending the Third World Water Forum in Kyoto, Japan, calling for

Column: 1454

help for 1.4 billion people without access to safe drinking water.

    Singapore has a lot to be grateful for. The shortage of our own source of water supply has made us venture into new sources of water, including NEWater and desalination. To me, NEWater represents the spirit of Singapore. We have shown that, in times of need, we would master technology and, with our strong will to protect our independence, we are willing to do what is necessary. The result is NEWater. But, I suppose the battle is not over, because there are Singaporeans who are still relatively uncomfortable with NEWater.

    Sir, my question is: what more is the Ministry doing to help Singaporeans to be more comfortable with NEWater, and what are the plans to use NEWater through the reservoirs? In fact, I was attending a meeting, and someone said, "Why is Singapore, which is very well-known for being pragmatic, not using NEWater directly for consumption, because it has been proven to be very clean and safe?" I agree with the approach taken by the Ministry of the Environment to take it step by step.

    I would like to know what the plans are, in terms of our use of more NEWater in our reservoirs. What are the challenges to NEWater in terms of acceptance, and how will the Ministry of the Environment manage it? I would also like to ask whether the Ministry would look at other technologies available, to make more new sources of water available.

    Mr S. Iswaran (West Coast): Sir, I welcome the various initiatives that the Ministry has taken to diversify and sustain Singapore's future water supply, and I think this has been a source of great reassurance to all Singaporeans. The Minister has used the vivid analogy of four taps, primarily the catchment water supply, Johor water, desalinated water and NEWater.

    The point that I wish to raise here is that the newer taps, specifically desalinated water and NEWater, are more

Column: 1455

energy-intensive sources of water supply. If we look at the new water process, in particular the aspects of ultra-filtration, reverse osmosis and ultra-violet treatment, as well as the desalination process, they entail a greater need for energy in order to generate the potable water supply.

    So, the question I have is whether we are substituting our reliance on imported water with a new dependence on imported oil or other sources of energy. Does this raise the question of a new vulnerability for Singapore, in the sense that our new source of water supply is now going to be dependent on the global oil market conditions? This point is particularly pertinent at this stage where there is considerable volatility in the global energy market. I would like to ask the Minister for his assessment of the new reliance on energy for our water supply, and whether there is a need to diversify, away from this vulnerability, through new technologies and, perhaps, new sources of energy as well. If so, what measures are being taken by the Ministry for that purpose?

    Mr Low Thia Khiang (Hougang): Sir, we are lucky to be able to take advantage of a new technology to produce NEWater, to avoid being arm-twisted by our neighbour, who proclaims to love our people's money. I am confident that, with the Government's multi-pronged approach on water provision, and with the many-taps-running concept, Singapore would be self-sufficient in our water supply in the future.

    I am of the view that being self-sufficient is not sufficient. To benefit the people, the effort in self-sufficiency in water must also translate into economic benefits for our people, ie, can Singaporeans benefit from lower water tariffs as a result of self-sufficiency in water supply? The deep sewer tunnel project is one that would provide the infrastructure for NEWater.

    With the development, water-borne fees were raised 100% some years ago. This has increased the total utility bill size for

Column: 1456

households. A water conservation tax of 30% was imposed on the first 40 cubic metres of consumption, which means that every household is subject to higher water bills, unless we do not use water at all. The rationale for this tax then was to gradually increase the water price, in anticipation of higher cost of water. Water consumption, at a higher quantity, is charged at a higher rate and tax.

    Sir, if we take all the charges and taxes in total, Singaporeans are paying a high water rate. I would like to know whether the water tariffs could be lowered, in view of the successful implementation of NEWater, which is less costly than expected. With the advancement in membrane technology, seawater desalination is also expected to cost less.

    Mr Othman Haron Eusofe: Sir, the availability of NEWater and desalinated water should not make us complacent. I am happy to note that the Ministry of the Environment has launched a comprehensive programme to educate the public on how to prevent wastage of potable water. What are the targets which the Ministry hopes to achieve in this water conservation programme?

    Sir, some domestic uses do not need potable water, eg, watering of plants, washing of void decks of HDB blocks, as well as the cleaning of commercial buildings. Would the Ministry consider a separate supply system of water to households and commercial users for non-potable usage?

    The Chairman: Mr Chiam See Tong is not present. Prof. Low Seow Chay.

    Assoc. Prof. Low Seow Chay: Sir, my cut is on the price of water. When the 1961 Water Agreement with Malaysia lapses, the alternative water supply will be through water recycling and desalination. As we know, the cost of water recycling is higher than the raw water supplied under the Water Agreement. One may worry about the potential rise in the water price after the series of NEWater plants are in operation.

Column: 1457



    The announcement of the desalination contract awarded to the private sector as a BOO project confirmed the cost of water from desalination. The contract price for desalination is about $0.80 per cubic metre, which is still lower than the current domestic charge of water even before the water conservation tax is included. In my view, the Government should be able to keep the price of water for a long time, unless the basic parameters, eg, the energy cost, change substantially.

    The man-in-the-street is worried about the rise in the water bill after the introduction of NEWater and the water from desalination. The question is: would the Ministry commit that the price of water for domestic use would be kept at status quo until the expiry of the 1961 Water Agreement?

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed: Sir, my topic is on waste minimisation. New water sources are one aspect of the need to educate Singaporeans about the value of water in Singapore. Minimisation of wastage is another. What are the plans to bring the message across to a wider cross-section of Singaporeans? Who are the worst wasters - commercial or residential users? What about hawker centres?

    We know that plastic bags and thimbles are being distributed free and that is a good way. But does ENV check whether those paraphernalia that are distributed are being applied in the households? If water use is still relatively unchanged after this campaign, what more will ENV do to minimise wastage?

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Sir, household recycling participation increased from about one in seven in 2001 when the Recycling Campaign was launched to about one in three currently. The target rate for this year is one in two households.

    Sir, I would like to ask the Minister if he thinks the target set for this year is

Column: 1458

achievable. What are the initiatives the Ministry would be adopting to achieve this target?

    The Environment Ministry should be commended for its unstinting efforts to promote recycling. Clearly, there is heightened awareness among Singaporeans about recycling. Nonetheless, unlike the urge to go to the stall with the longest queue, recycling is not second nature to most Singaporeans. Much more needs to be, and can be, done.

    Education efforts should be stepped up. Young and old must be educated not only on the virtues of recycling, but also on the ABCs and best practices of recycling. They need to be taught what can be recycled and what cannot be, so that trash does not end up in the recycling bins. They should be encouraged to separate their recyclables into different bags so that papers, for instance, do not get damaged by wet cans. My legislative assistant, who lived in Germany for 16 years, shared with me that she feels very uneasy each time she mixes her trash, as in Germany, households sort trash for recycling. In Singapore, we often find non-recyclable trash in recycling bins.

    Students should not only be taught the virtues of recycling and brought to visit landfills and incinerators. They should be given ample opportunities to put into practice what they learn. I would like to suggest to the Ministry that NEA organise a national recycling competition for schools to promote recycling among our young.

    Collection points for recyclable materials could be made even more accessible. In fact, for every two public trash bins, perhaps there should be one for recycling.

    Over time, residents could be weaned from using plastic bags which are environmentally unfriendly for storing recyclable items, with the provision of reusable crates such as those SembWaste is using for landed housing estates. In HDB estates, I support the idea that the Government could also look into providing two

Column: 1459

chutes, one for recyclables and another for non-recyclables.

    Sir, NEA has clearly made a very good headstart in promoting recycling. But more needs to be done. Singaporeans must learn to treasure trash!

    Mdm Cynthia Phua (Aljunied): Sir, I support Dr Amy Khor in commending the Ministry of the Environment for the efforts and progress that it has made in promoting recycling in homes and the achievements made that one in three households now recycle.

    My concerns are: what is the cost of collection of the recycled materials from house-to-house per household per month? What is the value of the recycled materials collected per household per month? What is the average volume of the recycled materials versus the average volume of the refuse per household? Would the refuse collection companies be able to sustain this door-to-door collection? What other alternatives has ENV explored?

    In addition, more education programmes should be emphasised in the following areas:

    Educate the people at home, the young and old, the school children, especially primary school children, where enthusiasm can still be cultivated on recycling and what can be recycled.

    Most households are familiar with the recycling of papers. Many do not know what are the materials that can be recycled, for example, glass, aluminium cans and bottles and at what stage must these materials be cleaned before they are thrown into the recycling bins.

    Have some education materials in Tagalog and Bahasa Indonesia to enable our maids to recycle too.

    I have noticed that ENV has introduced recycling bins in some of the public places, for example, Orchard Road, hawker centres and MRT stations. Are these suitable for homes to recycle? These

Column: 1460

would be suitable for small volumes of waste, most probably as a by-product of the activities at these places.

    I am suggesting that we designate some areas within HDB estates and private estates where recycling bins are there all the time where the refuse collection contractor collects daily. This could eventually be the more sustainable centres for collection of recycling materials in the long run and are near to the homes where larger volumes of recycling materials are available.

    Mr Iswaran: Sir, based on the Ministry's projections on its current waste generation and recycling rates, a new landfill is required once in every 25-30 years. That would mean that our current landfill at Pulau Semakau will probably last us till, say, 2030. From that point of view, this is a deadline that is far more imminent than our second Water Agreement with Malaysia which expires in 2061. It is more critical in the sense that land is not a renewable source unless we count reclamation. We really need to address this issue in a hurry, it seems to me, to ensure that landfill life is extended for as long as possible.

    I would like to raise the question from both the supply and demand side. From the supply side, clearly, this is not sustainable but it seems to me that we would need plans for at least one or two more landfills for the foreseeable future.

    The question that I have for the Minister is: what are the plans in that regard? But perhaps, more importantly, on the demand side, many speakers have alluded to the point on recycling. It seems to me that land is a strategic resource and providing additional landfill sites is going to be extremely costly for Singapore. Should we not be involved in a very intensive way in educating Singaporeans on the need to recycle and creating the right incentives and, dare I say it, disincentives, so that the behaviour adjusts to this reality?

    The Minister for the Environment (Mr Lim Swee Say): Sir, I was in China late last

Column: 1461

year. China right now is going through a very fast pace of change - urbanisation and industrialisation. Some of the officials that I met told me that one of the key concerns they face in China today is that, as they go through the fast pace of development, how do they ensure that the environment is protected so that, in time to come, the environment will continue to be liveable. I asked them, "How do you know? What kind of performance indicators would you use so that you know whether the environment is being protected?" They replied to me in Chinese. They said, "This is our target. Tian kong shi lan de. Yuan di shi lu de. Liu shui shi qing de. Kong qi shi tian de." Loosely translated, what he meant was the sky hopefully will remain blue, the land remains green, the water pure and clear, and the air will remain fresh.

    Sir, earlier, various MPs, Dr Teo Ho Pin and others, asked for an update of the environmental performance. So I asked my officials at NEA the same questions. I asked my officials, "Tell me, what is the colour of our sky?" And my colleagues in NEA told me, "Minister, we are okay. The sky is still blue and the air is fresh." I said, "On what basis did you come to that conclusion?" He said if we were to look at the pollutant standards index (PSI), in fact, since 1993, on the average, about 70% of the days in Singapore, the PSI is less than 50, which is in the good range. But in the last two years, it has gone up to more than 80%. In other words, the number of days in Singapore with PSI within the good range has gone up and that includes those days where we were affected by the regional haze. If we were to exclude the period of the regional haze, in fact, last year, 98% of the days in Singapore were within the PSI. If not for the regional haze, almost every day, we do enjoy good air quality in Singapore.

    Sir, I want to emphasise that this clear air and blue sky in Singapore did not happen by chance. Over the years, we have worked very closely with the industries to control emission from the industries. In fact, we are working very closely

Column: 1462

with the industries to promote the use of cleaner fuel as well. Take, for example, the generation of electricity. In the year 2000, about 19% of the electricity in Singapore was generated using natural gas. It has gone up to 47% last year, which means almost half of the electricity we use today is generated using natural gas, which is a source of cleaner energy. At the same time, we have also stepped up enforcement in monitoring, in terms of vehicle emissions. In fact, over the years, we have progressively tightened up on the emission standards and, together with enforcement standards, I am happy to inform the House that the percentage of smoky vehicles in Singapore has declined from 5.8% 10 years ago to 0.8% last year. So this combination of factors, emission control in the industries and vehicular emission, has led to a better quality of air in Singapore.

    Prof. Low Seow Chay asked whether two-stroke motorcycles are a problem and whether we can phase out two-stroke motorcycles completely. Sir, firstly, I want to clarify that the registration of two-stroke motorcycles has not stopped. Even today, anybody can still register a two-stroke motorcycle as long as the vehicle satisfies our emission standards. I agree with Prof. Low that the two-stroke motorcycles at times can be a problem because the design of the vehicle is such that the owner needs to mix the lubrication oil together with the petrol in the engine. And at times, if you were to add too much of the lubrication oil, the motorcycle will end up emitting white smoke. But I was told that the newer two-stroke motorcycles now come with this automatic pump and this pump will ensure that a correct dose of lubrication oil is being added. I want to inform Prof. Low that there is no plan at all for us to phase out the two-stroke motorcycles because we are not aware of any country in this world that has done so. As far as ENV is concerned, as long as any vehicle, whether it is two-stroke or four-stroke, satisfies our emission standards, it should be allowed on the road.

    Sir, let me move on to the area of weather forecast. None of the Members here asked me about the quality of our

Column: 1463

weather forecast. But I thought since we are talking about clean and fresh air, it is useful also to say a few words about the work put in by my colleagues in the area of weather forecasting.

    Sir, I remember sometime ago, we, including myself, often make fun of our weather forecast. Why? Because, without listening to the weather forecast, you and I know that the weather forecast will be "scattered showers at isolated places". Obviously, many of us did not find it very useful. But let us be very fair to our Weather Department because it is very difficult to forecast weather in a tropical island where the weather season is shorter and, therefore, it is very difficult for us to be accurate. But what the weather forecasting officials have done is that, since 1997, they have been fully aware that members of the public do expect a more useful form of weather forecasting. So, in 1997, we divided Singapore into various regions. In 1997, we started with five regions and, in the year 2000, it had gone up to 19 regions and, at this moment, they are working on 32 regions. What this means is that you can now actually ask for the weather forecast for a specific region because the whole of Singapore is now divided into 32 regions. Depending whether you are in Jurong or Tuas or wherever, you can ask for the weather forecast which is specific to that particular location.

    What is even more useful is that, instead of giving a 24-hour forecast, which is quite general and not specific enough, we are increasingly moving towards a three-hour forecast, what we call "now-cast". So far, based on the reaction from the public, it is clear that most of the public find this "now-cast" concept quite useful. For example, businesses are coming to us to ask for weather forecasts for specific areas of business operations. For recreation, there are times you may organise outdoor functions at West Coast Park, East Coast Park, and so on. In fact, we are getting more inquiries regarding the weather forecast for that particular location for the next three hours. Schools,

Column: 1464

for example, are coming to us to ask for lightning watch, and so on. In fact, last year, about 330,000 hits were recorded on our Internet homepage and 2.1 million Singaporeans actually accessed our hotline.

    What we are doing now is to work closely with the media to ensure that this improvement in the quality of forecast will lead to improvement in the quality of broadcast. There is no point having all these good forecasts if the information is not being broadcast to the public. So if you were to pay attention to our TV 5 News, for example, you will notice that the weather forecast today - and it has been going on for the last few weeks at least - is a graphical representation showing the weather forecast in the morning, afternoon and evening. So the forecast is now more specific. If you look at today's Lianhe Zaobao, again the weather forecast is represented in nice graphics, indicating the weather forecast for the different times of the day. If you listen to our radio, you will also notice that nowadays they will give you the weather forecast at about 16-17 times a day, and updated based on the latest 3-hour forecast. We hope that by working closely with the media, we will be able to provide better and more useful weather forecasts for members of the public.

    Sir, let me move on to the area of land. I asked my colleagues what is the colour of our land and they told me, "Minister, yes, it is still green and clean." In fact, in year 2001, the STB conducted a survey among the visitors to Singapore and 99% of them actually rated Singapore as a clean city. PERC did a survey last year for the expatriates. Again, they highlighted that the cleanliness of Singapore is one of the top three most attractive features of Singapore. Sir, the reason why we are able to continue to maintain a high standard of cleanliness in Singapore for public places is because ENV and NEA will never stop looking for new and better ways of keeping Singapore clean.

    Four years ago, we opened up public cleansing for competition by the private sector. Today, we have two companies

Column: 1465

cleaning the highways and roads, and they make use of very advanced equipment and machinery. They train their workers so that they can make use of this machinery in a most effective and productive manner. For example, one of the two companies, Onix, actually makes use of GPS to track the movement of their road-sweepers. At any point in time, the supervisor sitting in the control room will be able to look at the map and indicate the exact location of these mechanical sweepers. He is even able to tell whether the sweepers were just cruising or actually sweeping because all the information is being transmitted. This is very important because it enables them to make sure that areas that are supposed to be cleaned at a certain time of the day are actually being done.

    On the part of NEA, our officers likewise make use of IT. In fact, we have this Mobile Investigation Team (MIT) and they are all equipped with PDAs. Using the PDAs, they are now able to download any comments or feedback from the public channelled from our call centre. In fact, right at this moment, every day, we are able to respond to at least two out of three calls within the same day. Sir, as a result, the number of complaints regarding the cleanliness of Singapore has dropped by about 30%. choice - more subjects, different levels of subjects - but also wants to retain the trademark rigour and high standards of the Singapore system.

    Dr Amy Khor and Mdm Halimah have asked about preparing teachers for the changes. This is key to the successful implementation of the educational reforms. Specific training will be provided to teachers who are involved in the new curriculum, either in the teaching of new subjects, like Knowledge and Inquiry, or the new levels of subjects that we are going to introduce. We will spare no efforts on this. Our teachers are not, however, starting from scratch. While MOE will continue to train and update existing teachers and new teachers on the new curricula, I would like to emphasise that our teachers are already trained with a core of knowledge and skills that enables them to respond to changes in subject design and to adopt new modes of teaching.

    Mr Inderjit Singh has asked if we should extend the flexibility or unstructuredness of the new JC curriculum to the secondary level. This is an important issue that was studied carefully in last year's review by the JC and Upper Secondary Education Review Committee. The key issue at the JC level was over-specialisation. This problem does not exist at the secondary level. The lower secondary curriculum is already broad-based. At the upper secondary level, all express students must take at least one science, one humanities subject, mathematics, and two languages. In practice, among science students who take 8 `O'-level subjects, 62% of them take at least two humanities subjects and two languages, besides mathematics and science subjects. It is therefore not necessary to make significant changes to the secondary curriculum.

    However, I think the spirit of Mr Inderjit Singh's question is right. We are indeed seeking to introduce more flexibility and choice in the secondary school system. That is why we are creating new and different pathways for our students by introducing the integrated programmes, allowing the establishment of specialised independent schools in sports, arts and science, and allowing for a few privately funded secondary schools. These schools will be free to structure a curriculum that suits their objectives.

    We have also opened the door to mainstream schools that wish to adopt an alternative, internationally recognised curriculum. Further, we have introduced flexibility in the Normal (Academic) stream, as Minister Teo has just mentioned. And all schools have the autonomy to develop niches of excellence in their chosen areas. It is better that we focus on implementing these changes well and allow them to work through the system and be digested by parents and students before considering if we should introduce any further fluidity in the school system.

At last year's debate on the JC and upper secondary review, Members will recall that MOE has said that we expect to have up to 6-8 integrated programmes eventually, catering to the top 10% of each cohort. The four families of schools which have already received approval to offer integrated programmes, plan to start enrolling students for these programmes next year, 2004. They are currently developing their programmes and will be releasing more information in July or August, in time for this year's Primary 6 students and their parents to make informed decisions about whether to apply for the programmes. MOE has also recently received two additional proposals from schools which are keen to offer integrated programmes, and is evaluating them.

We have just introduced compulsory education, implemented this year for the first time, for the very reason of ensuring that all our young go through an essentially common shape of experience in their primary school years, and form similar instincts regardless of social background.

quite clearly to the public. good idea. Our teachers are not show-biz stars, they are very modest people, but I think a greater profile, through the course of the year, will enhance awareness of the real value of the teaching profession.

MOE completed a review of the school curriculum at all levels not long ago, in year 2001. Content has been reduced to free up more time for learning activities that foster critical and creative thinking. There is greater emphasis across the subject curriculum on process and thinking skills.

We changed the syllabus and examination format for the `A' levels to reward students who are able to apply the principles they have learnt and to think on their feet.

    MOE agrees fully with Dr Wang and the other MPs on the need to develop an entrepreneurial spirit amongst our young. There are basically two sets of skills and instincts that matter here, and that are reflected in our approach to developing this spirit among our students. The first comprises practical business-related skills. Our schools have been actively promoting this through co-curricular activities (CCAs), such as entrepreneurial clubs and business clubs of one form or another. There are many examples of schools whose students have started business ventures such as co-operatives or part-time businesses in schools. They were serious about what they were doing - so serious that they worked till 4 o'clock in the morning. I asked them how many would seriously contemplate setting up a business at some point in the future or doing so with a few friends. About one-third raised their hands. That is not bad. I think it is much higher than it would have been 2-3 years ago. So the flame is lit, and it is glowing.

    Even our primary school students are being infected, in their own fashion. There are many examples. Students in Rulang Primary School have grown a spice garden and have successfully sold their produce to school staff and parents. I am assured that they donated all proceeds to the SPCA.

Column: 1582

focus on key traits that underlie entrepreneurship: resourcefulness, persistence in the face of difficulty and the habit of innovation. These are traits that are useful for all our students, not just those who might eventually go on to run a business. We want our students to be willing to work out new perspectives, have the boldness and self-conviction to try another way, take a different road and, occasionally, break the mould. Efforts to develop these traits will be manifest in various facets of our school programmes, starting even in our primary schools.

But we can and will produce generations of Singaporeans who are able to face the future with confidence, try more diverse paths, persist against the odds and thrive.

MOE will continue, of course, to give schools the autonomy to decide on the setting up of such clubs as part of their overall school programme.

There is a whole host of programmes, in our schools and within school clusters, to cater to students with special talents and interests, in the arts, music and the sciences. At the JC level, the new curriculum will provide more space for this. In other words, within the formal curriculum, we want to provide more space for this. For example, the History paper now focuses more on questions requiring thinking skills and the application of concepts instead of content knowledge.

This difference in the scope of coverage means that the weaker students will be prepared sufficiently well to pass the 'O' levels, while the more able students will probably perform better.

    Our Secondary 5 students are, by and large, coping quite well with the `O' levels. About 66% of the students progress on to our post-secondary educational institutions. Of that 66%, 45% do well enough to qualify for either the polytechnics or 'A' levels.

They are also taught to make decisions based on moral principles in their civics and moral education lessons. Through Learning Journeys to places like PSA, JTC and Parliament House, which include observing parliamentary sessions from the gallery, they learn the critical issues and challenges facing Singapore and what makes Singapore tick.

    But we believe that it is not enough to just teach students these values in classroom lessons or take part in Learning Journeys. We must also provide opportunities for students to practise these values to learn what it means to

Column: 1632

have integrity, loyalty and understand why discipline and perseverance are important for success, and allow them to experience the joy of giving to the community. That is why MOE introduced the Co-curricular Activities (CCA) Programme Framework in 2001, comprising CCA and the Character Development Programme (CDP), of which the Community Involvement Programme (CIP) is one component.

    The Character Development Programme comprises a range of enrichment activities organised into the three domains of enterprise, citizenship, and personal and social development. There are specific activities under each domain. For example, schools organise creativity, innovation and problem-solving workshops for students to nurture enterprise.

    One of the values we nurture in our students is service to the community. This is achieved through the Community Involvement Programme (CIP). For example, students from Nanyang Girls High have adopted Block 151, Mei Ling Street in Queenstown, to serve the elderly who attend activities organised by the Lion Befrienders. Students are scheduled to visit and interact with the elderly in two-hourly sessions and learn the art of flower-making from the senior citizens. These flowers are later sold by the students to raise funds for the centre.

    How do we assess the effectiveness of the CDP and National Education? Values, such as perseverance and loyalty, are intangible and difficult to measure quantitatively. Nevertheless, we have developed proxy measures to review our National Education programmes, activities and CDP, and assess if they are effective. One of these is the CIP survey. Based on the 2002 survey, 91% of all our schools had at least 90% of their students completing six hours of CIP participation. This is an indirect measure of our students' readiness to contribute to the community in a small way. In the new JC curriculum to be introduced in 2006, JC students would need to meet minimum requirements in CCA and CDP participation.

    Mr Gan Kim Yong and Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon also asked whether our teachers are trained to deliver National Education and character development programmes, while Ms Braema Mathiaparanam asked if teachers are trained to deal with racial discriminatory attitudes. The answer is, yes, through formal and informal settings. NIE's National Education training and character development programmes prepare teachers for practice in the profession. To create awareness of National Education among trainee teachers, NIE infuses National Education issues into the respective course modules. It also holds a three-day National Education seminar annually, which is attended by all trainee teachers. Furthermore, a compulsory Singapore Studies module will be introduced for teachers in the NIE degree programme in July 2003.

    Training in character development is delivered through formal lessons in core and elective modules, where the values of care, integrity and being good role models are emphasised. Through these various training schemes, our young teachers are exposed to different modes of conducting lessons in character development and National Education. Incumbent teachers too are not neglected. They receive in-service training through workshops, seminars, sharing sessions and talks to equip them with the attitude, skills and knowledge to conduct character development and National Education lessons and activities. In addition, our teachers are sensitized to racial issues in schools, through talks by the principals, National Education seminars and sharing sessions. In school context, they are called "contact times". At regular school staff meetings, education officers also have the opportunity to discuss how to manage difficulties that might arise in their work environment, including discriminatory attitude should it occur.

    Madam, on racial integration, Dr Wang Kai Yuen and Mr Chandra Mohan asked how we could better promote racial

Column: 1634

integration in schools by inculcating tolerance and understanding of each other's culture and habits. Our national schools play an important role in teaching our students the importance of racial harmony and social cohesion. They have continued to organise multi-cultural celebrations of ethnic festivals, set up National Education or Heritage Corners, and work with parents and the Community Development Councils to broaden inter-racial mixing through the home-stay and home visit programmes.

    Through the curriculum, classroom activities and CCAs, our students have the opportunities to learn, understand and appreciate the cultures and traditions of their friends. I would say that the foundation for racial integration and harmony is laid very early in our schools. The Committee on Strengthening Racial Harmony in Schools introduced a framework for broadening and deepening racial harmony in schools last year. Earlier this year, a racial harmony website was launched to share best practices in promoting racial harmony in schools as well as to engage students to discuss and understand racial harmony issues better. The Committee also recommended the introduction of a set of racial harmony indicators to be included in the school excellence model (SEM), a self-appraisal tool for all schools. The racial harmony indicators are designed to assist schools in the management and evaluation of their own racial harmony programmes within the framework of the SEM.

    Mr Loh Meng See spoke about the importance of giving our students earlier exposure to cross-cultural environment. Madam, our racial harmony activities provide that exposure to our students. On top of that, our schools also organise International Friendship Day annually and some even work with foreign schools based here in Singapore in exchange programmes, so that our students and their students can mingle confidently, including during their home-stay.

    However, having said all these, I would like to stress that the child's experiences in school form only a part of his education. The family, the community and the

Column: 1635

society play no less a critical role in shaping the values of our young.

    Madam, on the Special Assistance Plan (SAP) schools, Mr Chandra Mohan and Mr Inderjit Singh asked how these schools promote racial harmony, considering their exclusive nature. I wish to assure Members that our SAP schools are aware of their responsibility for educating students who are steeped in our national values in a multi-cultural and multi-racial Singapore. They promote racial harmony and social cohesion as actively as other schools through the CIP, CDP, inter-school, cluster-based and community-based activities. Mindful that their school environment has limitations, they work with other schools to create opportunities for their students to interact with students of other races from other schools.

    One example is River Valley High where students celebrated the International Friendship and Racial Harmony Day with students from other schools in their cluster. Another example is Chung Cheng High School (Main), which has an exchange programme with Springfield Secondary, a school in Tampines, that provides opportunities for Chung Cheng students to interact with students of other races.

    The SAP schools were set up to preserve the best of the values and traditions found in the former Chinese schools. These traditions and values have created a richer environment and played a significant part in Singapore's development. Our SAP schools understand that they are an integral part of Singapore and accept the multi-racial nature of our society.

    Mr Chandra Mohan also suggested the setting up of SAP schools for Malays and Indians. We must bear in mind that the circumstances of each community are different and, therefore, may require different approaches to preserve their traditions. MOE set up two committees, involving representatives from the Indian and Malay communities, to review the teaching and learning of the Tamil and

Column: 1636

Malay languages in 1998 and 1999 respectively. The recommendations of the review to strengthen the teaching of Malay and Tamil languages were announced in year 2000. These included, among other things, the introduction of an Enrichment Programme in Malay Language for Secondary Schools, (in short, EMAS), Language Elective Programme (Malay Language) in Tampines JC and the upgrading of the Umar Pulavar Tamil Language Centre to a national Tamil Language Centre. It is heartening to note that the majority of the MLEP and EMAS students, both at the Tampines JC and Bukit Panjang Government High, have performed well in the 'A' and 'O' level examinations in Higher Malay Language examinations.

    Let me now deal with the specific issues raised by Members. First, sexuality education. Dr Maliki referred to sex education, but we do not teach sex education per se. What we do is to introduce sexuality education. Dr Maliki asked about the effectiveness of our sexuality education, and how the programme is being received. The aim of sexuality education is to equip students with the knowledge and skills to make responsible decisions on sexuality matters, based on values in line with the national value of the family as the basic unit of society. Sexuality education is implemented in schools through a cross-curricular approach in subjects such as Health Education, Science, and Civics and Moral Education. It is also carried out as a co-curricular programme based on the Growing Years series.

    For Dr Maliki's information, six to eight hours of sexuality education is taught every year. It is conducted outside curriculum hours as an enrichment programme. Teachers are also trained by medical practitioners, the police (in the case of legal matters, the legal aspect of sexuality issues), social workers as well as by psychologists. Pupils have responded well to the programme, showing a significant increase in their knowledge and understanding of sexuality matters. It is, however, too early to assess the impact of the programme on pupil's sexual

Column: 1637

values and attitudes, bearing in mind that the influences on them are so varied and very strong from many different sources.

    Dr Maliki also asked why teenage pregnancy has increased. The causes for teenage pregnancy are multi-faceted. They include a lack of family support and cohesiveness, history of sexual abuse and low esteem. Schools alone cannot address all these issues and causes. What we can do, through sexuality education for students, is to inculcate the right values, raise their awareness of the options and the consequences, and equip them with the skills to make informed decisions. The family and the community must also play their part to support the school.

    On school discipline, Mdm Ho Geok Choo said that principals should temper discipline with a heart. Indeed, we agree with Mdm Ho. Our schools have a multi-tier discipline system, complemented by a pastoral care and guidance programme. When a pupil shows signs of misconduct, he will be counselled first by teachers and, if necessary, by a professional MOE counsellor. Schools also work closely with parents to help the child. For recalcitrant pupils, schools will turn to external agencies like the MCDS, the Juvenile Court, Family Service Centres and self-help groups to help such pupils. Disciplinary actions, like expulsion and suspension, are only meted out as a last resort. Even then, schools will re-admit these pupils if they change their undesirable behaviour and commit to improve their conduct. Similarly here, schools cannot work alone. It requires the cooperation of parents and the community, and will continue to work with them to help these children.

    Madam, on physical education, Mr Ng Ser Miang said that physical education (PE) should be serious, yet fun, and teach sports and games. He wondered if we had sufficient time for PE compared to other countries. Our PE programmes do teach students to play different sports and games, and it is fun-filled and

Column: 1638

yet achieving its objectives of developing students' motor and games skills. Students also learn to keep fit and appreciate teamwork, fair play and sportsmanship through PE. Madam, we compare well with other developed countries, like the USA, in the time allocated for PE. For example, for Primary One to Primary Four, we have between 90-120 minutes of PE per week, compared to 100 minutes for the USA. I wish to assure Mr Ng and Dr Warren Lee that MOE does not encourage the use of PE periods for remedial lessons. All remedial lessons are supposed to take place outside curriculum hours.

    Mr Ng also asked if we have a sufficient number of PE teachers and whether NIE opens its PE programme to fee-paying students who are interested in a career in the sports industry. We have sufficient qualified PE teachers to meet our demands and we are able to recruit sufficient number of PE trainees every year. As NIE's PE training programme prepares our teachers to teach PE in our schools, it is not suitable for someone who is looking for training in preparation for a career in the sports industry.

    On the Trim and Fit Programme, I am very pleased to note that none other than Dr Warren Lee has brought up the issue of the importance of trim and fit. I say this because he is a paediatrician. I would like to thank Dr Warren Lee for calling the Trim and Fit Programme (or TAF) a success and wish to assure Mr Ng Ser Miang that all TAF activities are conducted outside curriculum hours. Dr Lee also asked our schools to encourage mass participation in sports, including obese students to play sports and games. We agree fully with Dr Lee. In line with our national policy of Sports for All, there are many avenues for our students, including obese pupils, to participate in sports today. They range from PE lessons, recreational CCAs, to games and competitions at various levels - the school level, cluster level, and at class level too.

    Since 1999, schools have been encouraged to adopt the house system for their CCAs to further promote mass participation in sports. Some schools have even

Column: 1639

made special efforts to entice overweight students to exercise by introducing roller-blading, boxercise, games and ethnic dances, to make exercising fun. Others conduct their TAF activities in the form of a CCA, such as the Health and Fitness Club or the Fun and Fitness Club. Some schools also conduct seminars, talks and sharing sessions on wellness to educate and encourage parents to support and promote a healthy lifestyle for them and their children. I am very glad to report to Members that parents, through the parents support groups, do help our teachers to conduct these activities for the obese pupils.

    In order to overcome the manpower and physical resources limitations, some schools are tapping on the Singapore Sports Council's Learn to Play Sports Basic Programme to increase sports opportunities for students. For example, St. Michael's Primary School has the beginners' soccer programme
